newsitem.title: GERMANY: German police comb countryside for kidnap victim.
newsitem.headline: German police comb countryside for kidnap victim.

text.p: German police with helicopters and tracker dogs scoured the countryside north of Frankfurt on Monday for clues to the whereabouts of kidnapped multi-millionaire Jakub Fiszmann, police said.

The 40-year-old businessman was abducted at the start of October. Fiszmann's brother Georg paid over a four-million-mark ($2.6 million) ransom on October 10 for his release, but his kidnappers failed to free him as promised the following day.
Hundreds of police searched the area of forest and fields, near the town of Idstein, after an anonymous phone call said cars had been seen in the locality.
Police thought the cars might have been involved in the kidnapping. They were also on the lookout for possible dug-outs in the earth which could be used to hide Fiszmann.
The last confirmation that Fiszmann was still alive came on October 2, one day after the kidnap during which he was injured in a scuffle.
Fiszmann telephoned a contact person, believed to be his girlfriend, saying he was being held by kidnappers in a cellar.
A ransom of 3.5 million marks ($2.3 million) was set, later raised to four million marks.

Fiszmann needs medication to treat specific food allergies so police are watching out for sales of the drugs Zyrtec, Lenen, Pulmicortnasal and Beconase in hopes of picking up a clue to where the abductors are located.
